Chiral Induced Synthesis of Helical Polypyrrole (PPy) Nano-
Structures: A Light-weight and High-Performance Material against
Electromagnetic Pollution
Aming Xie, ab Fan Wu, ab* Wanchun Jiang, b Kun Zhang, a Mengxiao Sun, b Mingyang Wang ab
Conducting polymers helical nano-structures have earned increasing attention because of their superior optical and electrical activities, light weight, flexibility as well as controllable morphologies at several levels of a hierarchy. Nevertheless, hardly any research has focused on helical conducting polymer nano-structures based electromagnetic protecting materials. Herein, we synthesized single-handed helical polypyrrole (PPy) nano-stuctures by a chiral inducing route and demonstrated their amazing electromagnetic protecting ability. Gradually constructed conducting network and helical chirality can be the main reasons for the tunable and impressive electromagnetic protecting performance of the asprepared helical PPy nano-structures. This research opens up an opportunity for the application of single-handed helical conducting polymer nano-structues as a light-weight and tunable high-performance electromagnetic protecting material, especially in fields of special aircraft, aerospace and fast-growing next-generation flexible electronics.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The applications of electromagnetic waves have been expanded extensively in recent years, yet generate severe adverse effects on human beings as well as sophisticated electronic equipment. To remove these harmful effects generated from electromagnetic radiation, significant effort has been made for the development of high-performance electromagnetic protecting (EMP) materials, especially the light-weight electrical conductive polymers that contained graphene oxide (RGO), 1,2 carbon nanotubes (CNTs), 3-5 conducting polymers, 6 and their composites. 7-9 The EMP effectiveness of a material critically depends on its dielectric constant, magnetic permeability and fillers connectivity. 6,7,10 It is reasonable to consider that in addition to both dielectric loss, magnetic loss should also be taken into account because it can distinctly enhance the electromagnetic attenuation. 11 Generally, the traditional way to improve magnetic loss is introducing the magnetic components into the materials. 12-14 Nevertheless, most intrinsic magnetic materials are of high density, low corrosion resistance and mixing inhomogeneity, which makes it unsuitable for comprehensive applications. Hence, materials exhibiting both dielectric and magnetic loss are strongly desired. On the other hand, high aspect ratio of conducting materials is beneficial for the formation of conducting network in the matrix, which improves the electric conductivity and dielectric constant as well as EMP effectiveness. 2 Lots of nano-fiber, -ribbon or -sheet based electrical
active materials and their hybrids, including conducting polymer, 15,16 RGO, 2,17 and CNTs, 3-5 have been developed as effective EMI shielding materials, by virtue of their high electrical activity, light weight, flexibility, and large aspect ratio. Therefore, high aspect ratio along with noteworthy dielectric and magnetic loss should be crucial for the rational design of high-performance EMP material.
Chirality exists widespread in biological systems as well as pharmaceutical area, of which the structure is not equal to its mirror image. 18 Chirality tends to form helical structures, a kind of crucial and common chiral structure exist across multiple material hierarchy in Nature, when transfer and express bottom-up during material formation generally. 19-22 Recently, chiral conducting polymers and their helical structures including fibers, tubes, and ribbons, have been paid increasing attentions on account of their unique electrical conductivities and optical activities together with special properties endowed by chirality. 23 However, hardly any research focusing on helical conducting polymer nano-structure based EMP materials has been reported, in spite of some chiral bulk PANi composites or chiral bulk schiff base coordination complexes which exhibited both enhanced dielectric and magnetic loss under electromagnetic radiation. 24,25 Different from meso-helix carbon nanocoils, 26 chiral helical conducting polymer nano-fibers could be single-handed, which can display distinctive electromagnetic interaction under electromagnetic waves, and thus may be desirable EMP material due to their superlight weight, high aspect ratio, as well as remarkable dielectric and magnetic loss.
As is well-known, polypyrrole (PPy) is one of the most common conducting polymers, and has been used in the field of EMP in recent years. 6,7,27 However, up to now, helical PPy nano-structures was scarcely reported, 28-30 especially their EMP properties. Herein,

we were the first time to systematically explore the EMP properties of a helical PPy nano-tube and a helical PPy nano-fiber. The helical PPy nano-tube was prepared using a chiral amino acid amphiphile as the inducing reagent, while the helical nano-fiber was synthesized by a soft gel-template route. By virtue of the high aspect ratio, light weight and helical nano-structure, both the helical PPy nano-tube and -fiber displayed amazing EMP performances under low filler loading ratio, which made it possess huge potential in the applications of EMP. Well-constructed conducting network and enhanced circular polarization were thought to be the main reasons for the impressive EMP ability of these helical PPy nano-structures.

sections.heading: Experimental Section
sections.text:
Materials. Inducing reagents N-myristoyl-L-glutamic acid (L-MGA) and N-myristoyl-D-glutamic acid (D-MGA) were synthesized according to the previous research. 31 Gelator N-myristoyl-Ldiglutamic acid (L-MDGA) was synthesized according to a modified process in the previous research. 32 Pyrrole monomer, ammonium persulphate (APS), and other reagents were all purchased and used without further purification.
Synthesis of Helical PPy nano-tubes. The Helical PPy nano-tubes were prepared according to the reported method with some modification. Typically, L-MGA or D-MGA (30 mg) and pyrrole (2 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of ethanol (EtOH) with the assistant of sonication. Then, 60 mL of deionized water was added and stirred for 20 min. Under ice bath, APS (2 mmol) was dropwise added to the above solution and stirred for 30 min. A black solid was obtained after filtrating, washing with water and EtOH, drying under vacuum. The L-MGA and D-MGA induced helical PPy nanotubes were named LHT-PPy and DHT-PPy.
Synthesis of Helical PPy nano-fibers. L-MDGA (200 mg) was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water by heating at 80 degrees. After cooling to room temperature, a transparent gel formed and dispersed into 1 L deionized water with stirring for 24 hours to furnish gel dispersion. Pyrrole (2 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of EtOH with the assistant of sonication. Then, 80 mL of the gel dispersion was added and stirred for 20 min. Under ice bath, APS (2 mmol) was dropwise added to the above solution and stirred for 30 min. A black powder was obtained by filtrating, washing with water and EtOH, and drying under vacuum. The L-MDGA templated helical PPy nano-fiber was named LHF-PPy.
Characterization. The detailed morphologies of the prepared helical PPy nano-tubes and -fibers were observed with a field emission high resolution transmission electron microscope (FE-HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F20UTwin, FEI) and a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, S4800, Hitachi). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded using a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). Raman spectroscopy was carried out using a Renishaw in Via Raman Microscope, equipped with a 514 nm laser. Fourier transfor infrared (FT-IR) was recorded on a Nicolet iS10 instrument. The experimental scattering parameters S11 (or S22) and S21 (or S12) were measured by a vector network analyzer (VNA, N5242A PNA-X, Agilent) in the frequency range of 2-18 GHz. In a
coaxial wire analysis, εr and μr were calculated from the scattering parameters based on the standard Nicolson-Ross-Weir (NRW) algorithm. 33,34 The measured samples were prepared by uniformly mixing with wax at 85 ° C. The mixture was then pressed into toroidal shaped samples with an outer diameter of 7.00 mm and inner diameter of 3.04 mm. For the measurement by the Arch method, the sample LHT-PPy was mixed with epoxy resin and sprayed on an 18×18 cm aluminum plate. The thickness of coating was fixed at 2.4 mm.

sections.heading: Results and discussions
sections.text:
Usually, PPy prepared by common oxidation method only furnished irregular granular micro-stuctures. 6,35
When adding V2O5 or cationic
surfactant as the auxiliary reagent, the microtopography appeared as regular nano-fiber, nano-tubes or nano-clips, indicating that the morphology of PPy was greatly influenced by additives. 36-38 If using chiral auxiliary amphiphile instead, pyrrole monomer tended to form supramolecular helice by a chirality transfer and magnification process. 18 In this research, L-MGA and D-MGA were employed as the chiral inducing reagents, respectively. Both LHT-PPy and DHTPPy showed helical tubular topographies with a diameter around 80 nm and hollow channel inside (Fig. 1). It was found that the helical directions of LHT-PPy and DHT-PPy were strictly opposite, appearing single-handed helical conformations (Fig. 1a,b).
Fig. 1 SEM images of LHT-PPy (a) and DHT-PPy (d); TEM images of LHT-PPy and (b, c) and DHT-PPy (e, f).
The formation mechanism of the helical PPy nano-tubes was discussed. Take LHT-PPy as an example, the inducing process can be depicted in Scheme 1. L-MGA can be easily dissolved in EtOH, but was insoluble in water. On account of its amphiphilicity and chirality, L-MGA tended to self-assemble and form helice in the mixture of EtOH/H2O, which can be directly observed as suspended white solid. Then, the carboxyl group of L-MGA can bind pyrrole through the weak acid-base interaction and made the pyrrole molecule possess positive charge. As a result, the pyrrole binding on L-MGA helice was greatly activated and preferred to be oxidized by APS to form seeds. Finally, residual pyrrole polymerized on seeds and helical PPy nano-structures formed. The DHT-PPy was induced by a similar process, in spite of the opposite helical directions.

On the basis of the induction by L-MGA, the hydrophobic moiety of helice was loose, and its actual length can be tuned by content of EtOH. The more volume of EtOH was added, the narrower hollow channel formed, which was in accordance with previous research. 28 However, the channel inside was not disappeared even if using the maximal content of EtOH on the premise of the successful formation of helical nano-structure. Aspiral PPy nano-tube displayed significant much lower conductivity than that of corresponding nano-fiber, 37 resulting in much difference in the EMP performance between helical PPy nano-tube and -fiber. It was assumed that if using lower rigid hydrophobic chain instead of loose hydrophobic moiety of L-MGA, helical PPy nano-fiber may form. Hence, L-MDGA, an amphiphile with two L-glutamic acid and one rigid hydrophobic chain, was synthesized and used for the induction of PPy. Quite different from L-MGA, L-MDGA formed helice in pure water through a sol-gel transformation process at different temperature. In EtOH/H2O mixture, L-MDGA only tended to selfassemble to particles. In our strategy, we first dissolved L-MDGA in hot H2O and cooled to room temperature to for a chiral gel, which contained large amount of self-assembly helices (Fig. 3a). Then, we dispersed the chiral gel into ten times volumes of H2O to prepare soft-template dispersion (Fig. 3a). The activate pyrrole binding on LMDGA helice preferred to be oxidized and formed seeds. Finally, a helical PPy nano-fiber was obtained with a much narrower diameter around 40 nm but no hollow channel inside, evidenced by the SEM and TEM images (Fig. 3b-d). Obviously, the as-prepared LHF-PPy displayed a single-handed helical feature (Fig. 3c).
Fig. 3 Inducing process for LHF-PPy (a); SEM images (b and c) and TEM image (d) of LHF-PPy;.
In addition to micro-structures, these as-prepared helical nanotubes and -fiber were consistent with common PPy particles or aerogels in elemental composition, chemical structure, and crystal form, evidenced by XPS, FT-IR, and Raman spectra (See Fig. S1-3 in ESI). 6 Based on the different attenuating mechanisms, EMP materials can be mainly divided into two types: electromagnetic absorbing (EMA) and electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding. The EWA performance of a material can be evaluated by reflection loss (RL) value. On the basis of transmission line theory and the model of metal backplane (See Scheme S1 in ESI), 39 the RL value can be expressed as follow, (1) √ (2)

When the RL is lower than −10, −20 or −30 dB, it means more than 90 %, 99 % or 99.9 % of the electromagnetic energy is absorbed. Generally, the bandwidth with RL values lower than −10 dB can be deemed as an effective EWA bandwidth.
Sole helical direction did not influence the EWA performance of a material, and thus comparative EWA ability can be obtained from LHT-PPy and DHT-PPy because of their similar electric conductivity, circular polarization, aspect ratio, dielectric constant and magnetic permeability. However, with the increasing content of LHT-PPy in composite, the EWA performance decreased sharply (Fig. 4b,c). Different from LHTPPy, 4 wt. % of LHF-PPy in the composite displayed relatively lower EWA ability (Figure 4d). But excellent dissipation of incident electromagnetic wave could take place at a relative higher filler loading (7 wt. %) (Fig. 4e). Similar to LHT-PPy, higher content of DHC-PPy is also not beneficial to EWA (10 wt. %) (Fig. 4f).
Fig. 4 RL curves of LHT-PPy (a-c) and LHF-PPy (d-f) with the filler loading ratio from 4 to 10 wt. % in the composites. The test frequency is increased from 2 to 18 GHz.
Generally, the frequency range with RL values lower than −10 dB can be seen as an effective EWA bandwidth. The effective EWA bandwidth of a composite loaded with 7 wt. % of LHF-PPy can reach 7.04 GHz ranging from 10.60 to 17.64 GHz under a thickness of 2.4 mm (Fig. 5a). After comparing with many reported works, it is hard to find any material that can reveal such broadband absorbing performance at such low filler loading ratio (Table S1 in ESI). RL curves measured by the arch method overall shift down slightly and the absorption range broaden to 7.2 GHz at maximum compared with the calculation by the transmission reflection coaxial line method (Fig. 5b). This sufficiently demonstrates that the RL value calculated by the transmission reflection coaxial line method is enough to depict the EWA performance. The applications of electromagnetic waves usually based on typical frequency bands, such as Ku band (12-18 GHz) for satellite broadcasting, X band (8-12 GHz) for synthetic aperture radar and electron spin resonance apparatus, C band (4-8 GHz) for microwave communications, and S band (2-4 GHz) mobile phones. Both LHT and LHF-PPy can effectively dissipate incident electromagnetic waves in the whole Ku and X bands under the thicknesses of 2.3 and 3.3 mm, respectively, where a lower filler loading ratio (4 wt. %) was required for LHT-PPy while 7 wt. % for LHF-PPy (Fig. 5c and d). Therefore, the EWA performance of helical PPy nano-structures surpassed most light-weight EWA materials.
In addition, the EMI shielding efficiency (SE) of the composites loaded with LHT and LHF-PPy can be evaluated by the measured loss of transmitted electromagnetic waves rather than reflected electromagnetic waves (See Scheme S1 in ESI). It can be found that the EMI SE increases apparently with the increasing thickness, and thickness effect is more noticeable for electromagnetic wave at high frequency than that at low frequency (Figure 6c and d). Higher filler loading ratio of LHT or LHF -PPy in the composite is beneficial to high-efficient EMI shielding (Figure 6e and f). For LHT-PPy, the EMI SE can exceed 10 dB covering whole frequency range from 2 to 18 GHz with only 16 wt. % in the composite under a thickness of 1 mm (Fig. 6c), which surpasses many reported nano-materials based EMI shielding composites (See Table S2 in ESI). It is worthy to point out that helical PPy is a very rare material that can reveal excellent both EWA and EMI shielding performance, simultaneously.
Fig. 6 3D plots of EMI SE performance of the composite loaded with different ratio (4-16 wt. %) of LHT (a) and LHF (b) -PPy; the EMI SE curves of the composites loaded 16 wt. % of LHT (c) and LHF (d) - PPy under different thicknesses (1-6 mm); the EMI SE curves of LHT (e) and LHF (f) -PPy under the thickness of 1 mm, meanwhile the filler loading ratios of LHT and LHF -PPy are increased from 4 to 16 wt. %.
To understand the EWA and EMI shielding mechanisms of helical PPy nano-structures, the relative complex permittivity and permeability were obtained from a vector network analyzer (VNA) and analyzed. The lager aspect ratio of helical PPy leads to better formation of conducting network in the composite, 7,10 thus results in significantly elevated both ε′ and ε″ values comparing with PPy particles at the same filler loading ratio in the composites (Figure 7a,b). 35 Take LHT-PPy as an example, it is observed that both ε′ and ε″ values linearly increased depending on the filler loading ratio (Figure 7e,f). However, under a same filler loading ratio, LHT-PPy reveal higher permittivity than LHF-PPy (Figure 7a,b,e,f), therefore causes an increment in electric conductivity, and obtains better EMI SE (Figure 6a-f). 10 It is strongly demonstrated that the micromorphology of helical PPy has an distinctly effect on its EMP ability. Different from achiral nano-material composites, the μ′ of helical PPy nano-structures cannot be neglected as well as the μ″, especially in the frequency range of 8-18 GHz (Figure 7c,d,g,h). As a result, it leads to magnetic loss, which usually originates from ferromagnetic materials. 11-14,26,41 The μ′ value changes non-linearly with the increasing filler loadings and can reach 1.18, even higher than some ferromagnetic materials in the high frequency range, 13,26,41-43 indicating improved magnetic storage ability of electromagnetic energy toward traditional dielectric materials. And additional magnetic loss satisfied the input impedance matching, which in favor of incident microwave attenuating.

Comparing with the traditional achiral materials, the main specialty for LHT and LHF -PPy is the helical structure. Under the radiation of electromagnetic waves, an inductive current can be induced in this helical structure according to the Faraday’s low. 44 Meanwhile, circular polarization will take place, and hence polarizes to form right-handed circular polarized (RCP) and/or left-handed circular polarized (LCP) waves, regardless of LHT-PPy and LHF-PPy (Scheme 2). According to the previous study, the speed of circular polarized waves are not equal to that of introduced electromagnetic waves, resulting significant increased attenuation of electromagnetic waves than nonchiral materials. 44 In addition, circular polarization greatly increases polarization relaxation of π-electron or defects, and further improves the attenuating ability. 1 On the basis of the analysis above, we can conclude that the superior EMA and EMI shielding performances of these special nano-structures were attributed to their high aspect ratios and especially increased circular polarizations.
Scheme 2 Circular polarization model of helical PPy nanostructures.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In conclusion, we have demonstrated the high-performance of light-weight helical PPy nano-structures in electromagnetic protection. Single-handed helicity of hollow PPy nano-tubes has been induced by chiral reagent L-MGA or D-MGA, respectively. The polymerization of PPy induced by L-MDGA tends to from single-handed PPy nano-fiber instead of nanotube. An acid-base interaction, activation, and seeding
mechanism can be used to illustrate the formation of helical PPy nano-structures. These helical PPy nano-structures show striking EMA performance under low filler loadings while excellent EMI SE at relative high filler loadings, indicating its tunable electromagnetic protecting ability. As EWA materials, LHF-PPy nano-fibers can reach 7.04 GHz of effective absorbing width in the range of 10.6-17.64 GHz only with the filler loading ratio of 7 wt. % in composite, which exceeds most reported materials. In addition, both LHT-PPy and LHF-PPy are effective EWA materials for both X (8-12 GHz) and Ku (12-18 GHz) bands. For EMI shielding, the SE higher than 10 dB covers a frequency range from 2 to 18 GHz only under the thickness of 1 mm. It opens up the opportunity for the application of helical conducting polymer nano-fibers as a light-weight and tunable high-performance electromagnetic protecting material, especially in fields of special aircraft, aerospace and fast-growing next-generation flexible electronics.
